introduction.p: You may save your work at any time by clicking on Save. When you are finished working, click on Submit and Finish, a pop up window will ask "This will submit your answers and finish this assignment. Are you sure?", click "OK" if you are ready to submit your answers for final grading.
If you close this window without having saved or submitted, your changes will be lost. After pressing Submit and Finish, please wait for your answers to be scored. Do NOT click on it more than once.

body.p: Why would an increase in the viscosity of blood be potentially dangerous?

input.choice: It would make it harder for blood to flow through the vessels.
It would decrease the ability of the blood to fight infection.
It would make the blood too acidic for chemical reactions to occur.
It would change the coloration of the blood.

feedback.p: Correct. The viscosity affects the ability of the liquid to flow. If the blood becomes more viscous, it can reduce its ability to flow freely.
Incorrect. A change in the leukocyte number or function would impact the ability of the blood to fight infection.
Incorrect. A change in the pH of the blood can impact the ability of enzymes to perform chemical reactions.
Incorrect. A color change occurs because of changes in the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin.

body.p: Which of the following is found in plasma but not in serum?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Albumin is one of the most common proteins in both plasma and serum.
Incorrect. Bicarbonate is one of the electrolytes found in both serum and plasma.
Correct. Serum is plasma that the blood clotting proteins have been removed from.
Incorrect. Urea is a metabolic waste product found in both serum and plasma.

body.p: Hypoalbuminemia can result from liver disease or abnormal nutrient absorption.
If there is not enough albumin in the plasma you would expect to see __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Difficulties in clotting can result from too little fibrinogen.
Correct. Edema is tissue swelling which can be caused by a lack of albumin in the blood.
Incorrect. Decreased immune function could occur due to a lack of gamma globulins.
Incorrect. Excessive blood clots could form from too much fibrinogen not a lack of albumin.

body.p: Which plasma protein is not made in the liver?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Albumins are synthesized by the liver.
Incorrect. Alpha and Beta globulins are manufactured primarily in the liver.
Incorrect. Fibrinogen is synthesized by the liver.
Correct. Gamma globulins are synthesized by lymphocytes (white blood cells) and act as the antibody defense against antigen invasion.

body.p: Which of the following correctly describes coagulation?

input.choice: results in constriction of the blood vessels
results in the formation of a thrombus

feedback.p: Incorrect. Vasoconstriction is one of the three major activities of hemostasis.
Correct. The formation of a clot or thrombus is the function of coagulation.
Incorrect. Platelet aggregation is one of the three major activities of hemostasis.
Incorrect. Hemostasis consists of three main activities, of which coagulation is one.

body.p: Why does the liver secrete the inactive protein fibrinogen instead of its active form, fibrin?

input.choice: Fibrin would disrupt the negative feedback loop.
Fibrin is too big to be carried in the blood.
Fibrin could be degraded too fast.
Fibrin could form dangerous unwanted clots.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Fibrinogen is an inactive molecule so it does not immediately contribute to clot formation. Blood clotting is a positive feedback loop.
Incorrect. Fibrinogen is inactive so it does not immediately start forming clots. The fibrin molecule itself is smaller than fibrinogen, so when they polymerize together, they form the long fibers.
Incorrect. Fibrinogen needs to be inactive so it does not immediately start forming clots.
Correct. By requiring specific pathways to activate fibrinogen to fibrin we protect ourselves from unwanted clots.

body.p: Which pathway accounts for blood still clotting even outside of the body?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Extrinsic pathway requires chemical signals from damaged cells.
Correct. The intrinsic pathway allows blood to still clot outside of the body in a test tube.

body.p: Which of the following chemicals are required for both the extrinsic and intrinsic pathways?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although Fibrin is required to be turned to the active form fibrinogen the other chemicals are necessary as well.
Incorrect. Although Thrombrin is required to be turn fibrin into the active form fibrinogen the other chemicals are necessary as well.
Incorrect. Calcium is required for both pathways but so are the other chemicals.
Correct. All of these chemicals are required for both pathways.

body.p: A deficiency of vitamin K and calcium would result in __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Both vitamin K and calcium are required for clotting, if they are deficient clotting will be reduced.
Incorrect. Excessive coagulation would be the same as excessive clotting and would require both calcium and vitamin K.
Incorrect. Thromboemboli are blood clots that travel through the blood. Vitamin K and calcium are required for clotting so these would not form as well with a deficiency of these chemicals.
Correct. There would be excessive bleeding because calcium and vitamin K are required for clotting. If the blood cannot clot there will be excessive bleeding.

body.p: Which of the following is the role of plasmin?

input.choice: splits the fibrin polymers that make up the clot
plays a role in producing bradykinin

feedback.p: Correct. Plasmin is the active form of plasminogen and will help break up clots by splitting the fibrin polymers.
Incorrect. Kallikrein plays a role in the production of bradykinin.
Incorrect. Bradykinin stimulates vasodilation.
Incorrect. Kallikrein activates plasminogen by converting it to plasmin.

body.p: Which cells are not involved in hemostasis?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Vascular smooth muscle cells are responsible for vasoconstrinction, the first step of hemostasis.
Incorrect. The aggregation of platelets (formation of a “platelet plug”) is the second step of hemostasis.
Correct. There is no such thing as clot cells. Platelets (thrombocytes) and fibrin are involved in the formation of blood clots.

body.p: Coagulation can be inhibited in a number of different ways. Which is not a way to prevent coagulation of drawn blood?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Some blood collection devices have heparin, which binds to thrombin to inactivate it.
Incorrect. Removing calcium prevents the coagulation cascade, but this should only be done outside the body.
Incorrect. Citric acid is a calcium chelator.
Correct. Extra calcium will disturb the clotting cascade, but it will not inhibit it.

body.p: Which of the following are not actually cells but are fragments of cells with no nucleus?

feedback.p: Incorrect. These are red blood cells which do lack a nucleus when mature but are still cells.
Incorrect. These are white blood cells that have a nucleus and other organelles.
Incorrect. These are a category of white blood cells that have a nucleus and other organelles.
Correct. Thrombocytes are platelets that bud off of larger megakaryocytes.

body.p: Which type of blood cells is sometimes not even classified as a cell?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although at maturity red blood cells do not contain a nucleus or many organelles, they are still considered to be cells.
Incorrect. Granulocytes contain nuclei, organelles and cytoplasm throughout their life span and are considered to be cells.
Incorrect. Leukocytes contain nuclei, organelles and cytoplasm throughout their life span and are considered to be cells.

Correct. Thrombocytes also known as platelets are fragments of larger cells called megakaryocytes and are sometimes not classified as cells because they only have a plasma membrane surrounding a small portion of cytoplasm and a few organelles.

body.p: What percentage of oxygen carried by the hemoglobin of RBCs diffuses into the cells of the body?

feedback.p: Incorrect. More than 10% of the oxygen carried will diffuse into the tissue.
Correct. 25% of the oxygen carried will diffuse into the tissue.
Incorrect. Less than 50% of the oxygen carried will diffuse into the tissue.
Incorrect. Less than 75% of the oxygen carried will diffuse into the tissue.

body.p: Which element in hemoglobin binds to oxygen?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Calcium is required for blood clotting., It is not part of the heme group.
Incorrect. Sodium id an important molecule but is not part of the heme group.
Incorrect. Magnesium is not part of the heme group.
Correct. Iron is the element in the heme group that oxygen binds to.

body.p: Where does the globulin portion of the hemoglobin molecule go after a RBC has been phagocytized?

input.choice: It is stored by binding to ferritin.
It is transported in the blood by transferrin.
It is degraded and dispersed in the blood plasma.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The heme portion of the hemoglobulin can be stored by binding to ferritin.
Incorrect. The heme portion of the hemoglobulin can be transported by transferrin.
Incorrect. Hemosiderin is a protein that can bind to the iron of the heme portion for storage.
Correct. The protein portion or the globin is degraded into amino acids then dispersed with in the blood plasma.

body.p: Which of the following two conditions arise from mutations in the genes?

input.choice: Pernicious anemia and folic acid deficiency anemia
Iron deficiency anemia and pernicious anemia
Hemolytic anemia and folic acid deficiency anemia

feedback.p: Correct. Both of these result form mutations in the hemoglobin protein.
Incorrect. Both of these types of anemia result from a poor intake/absorption of a dietary nutrient not a genetic mutation.
Incorrect. Both of these types of anemia result from a poor intake/absorption of a dietary nutrient not a genetic mutation.
Incorrect. Both of these can result from drugs.

body.p: What microscopic anatomical characteristics describe a red blood cell, other than the red color?

input.choice: large granules of hemoglobin throughout the cytoplasm

feedback.p: Correct. Unlike other blood cells, red blood cells look like floppy disks, not spheres.

Incorrect. Red blood cells actually are one of the few cell types that doesn’t have a nucleus; nuclei are shed during the red cell maturation process to make cells more compliant and make room for more hemoglobin.
Incorrect. Some white blood cells have granules, but the hemoglobin in red blood cells is soluble in the cytoplasm.
Incorrect. Some white blood cells have granules, but the hemoglobin in red blood cells is soluble in the cytoplasm.

body.p: What component of the blood makes it red?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Oxygen binding to the heme enhances the red color, but oxygen by itself is not red.
Incorrect. Plasma is the part of blood that contains soluble proteins in fluid.
Correct. Heme, part of hemoglobin found in red blood cells, gives blood its red color.
Incorrect. Electrolytes are another term for ions in solution. Like adding table salt to water, electrolytes do not provide any color to solutions.

body.p: A person of blood type O can safely receive which of the following blood types?

feedback.p: Correct. People with blood type O have anti-A and anti-B antibodies in their plasma. Therefore they cannot safely receive any blood type containing A or B antigens on the red blood cells, and are limited to transfusions of their own blood types.
Incorrect. A person with type O blood has anti-A and anti-B antibodies in their plasma, which would react with both surface antigens.
Incorrect. A person with type O blood has anti-A and anti-B antibodies in their plasma, which would react with the surface antigens of the AB blood cells.
Incorrect. A person with type O blood has anti-A and anti-B antibodies in their plasma, which would react with the surface antigens of A, B and AB blood cells.

body.p: Which of the following are lymphocytes?

feedback.p: Incorrect. PMNs are a type of granulocyte not a lymphocyte.
Incorrect. Eosinophils and basophils are both granulocytes and not lymphocytes.
Incorrect. Monocytes are agranular, but they are not lymphocytes.
Correct. The B-lymphocytes and T-lymphocytes are the two agranulocytes that are lymphocytes.

body.p: The use of corticosteroids (as opposed to anabolic steroids) can cause which of the following conditions?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Leukocytosis can result from situations such as viral infections.
Correct. Leukopenia can result form the use of steroids such as cortisone. This is one reason why corticosteroids decrease your immune function.
Incorrect. Leukemia is caused by a cancerous proliferation of WBCs.
Incorrect. Neutropenia is often caused by radiation or chemotherapy.

body.p: Which of the following is the smallest formed element of the blood?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Albumin is not a formed element of the blood, it is a plasma protein.
Correct. Platelets are the smallest formed elements in the blood.
Incorrect. Erythrocytes are bigger than platelets but smaller than Leukeocytes.
Incorrect. Leukeocytes are the largest formed elements in the blood.

body.p: The main function of platelets is to __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The leukocytes play a role in the prevention of infection.
Incorrect. The erythrocytes transport oxygen.
Incorrect. The basophiles play a role in the inflammatory response.
Correct. The platelets are the cellular components of hemostasis, which reduces blood loss.

body.p: Hematopoiesis occurs __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although the blood cells move through the veins they are not formed there.
Incorrect. The yellow bone marrow contains mainly adipose tissue (fat).
Correct. The red bone marrow is where the formed elements of the blood are made.
Incorrect. The lymph nodes are where lymphocytes are exposed to antigens.

body.p: VEGF is involved in which function of the endothelial cells?

input.choice: signaling after mechanical stress is sensed

feedback.p: Correct. Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) plays a role in angiogenesis or the formation of new blood vessels.
Incorrect. Cytokines from the immune system will cause a response in endothelial cells.
Incorrect. Endothelial cells do communicate about the environment to the smooth muscle cells adjoining them, but they do not use VEGF to do so.
Incorrect. Intact endothelial cells prevent clots by releasing prostacyclin.

body.p: Which of the following is not an example of a situation where the smooth muscle cells would adjust their tone (degree of contraction)?

input.choice: All of these will stimulate the smooth muscles to adjust their contraction.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Hormones released as a result of exercise can cause the smooth muscles to contract resulting in vasoconstriction.
Incorrect. Hormones released as a result of anxiety can cause the smooth muscles to contract resulting in vasoconstriction.
Incorrect. Nitric oxide can cause vasodialation resulting from smooth muscle cell relaxation.
Correct. All of these signals would cause vascular smooth muscle to decrease their tone (i.e. relax).

body.p: Why would arteries have a thicker layer of collagen (tunica externa) than veins?

input.choice: Arteries carry blood that is moving at a higher velocity.
Veins carry blood that is less oxygenated, and the thinner layer provides less distance for diffusion.
Veins contain blood at a higher pressure.
Arteries contain blood at a higher pressure.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Arteries do carry blood that is moving at high velocities, but this does not affect the thickness of the collagen layer.
Incorrect. Veins Veins do carry blood that is less oxygenated, but they do not participate in gas exchange. The degree of oxygenation does not affect the collagen content.
Incorrect. Veins contain blood that is coming back to the heart and so it is at a lower pressure than the blood exiting the heart.
Correct. The arteries receive blood straight from the heart so it is under high pressure. The collagen layer provides the strength that prevents the high pressure vessels from rupturing.

body.p: Which cell type of the myocardium is responsible for carrying and coordinating the action potentials in the ventricles?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The pacemaker cells spontaneously depolarize and start the action potential.
Incorrect. Nodal cells are another name for the pacemaker cells that spontaneously depolarize and start the action potential.
Correct. The conducting cells found in the bundles of His and the Purkinje fibers carry the signal and coordinate the contraction of the ventricles.
Incorrect. The myocardial cells are a type of muscle tissue that allows the heart to beat as one unit.

body.p: Which of the following is not a characteristic of cardiac muscle cells in comparison to skeletal muscle cells?

feedback.p: Correct. Cardiac muscle has intercalated disks that connect neighboring muscle cells, allowing them to pass the electrical signals and contract as a group (syncytitum).
Incorrect. Both cardiac muscle and skeletal muscle require oxygen to create energy for sustained contractions.
Incorrect. Although cardiac muscle has a greater mitochondrial density than skeletal muscle, they both contain multiple mitochondria per cell.
Incorrect. Although many cardiac cells have only one nucleus, there are some that have two, such that multiple nuclei are not unique to skeletal muscle.

body.p: Which of the following is not a characteristic of cardiac pacemaker cells?

input.choice: a low permeability to potassium in their resting state
a more positive resting potential that changes slowly
a dependence on external calcium for creating an action potential
rapid depolarization is a result of the opening of voltage-gated sodium channels.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Cardiac pacemaker cells do have a low permeability to potassium in their resting state which helps keep their resting potential more positive.
Incorrect. The resting potential of cardiac pacemaker cells is less negative and their resting potential will slowly change as they prepare to depolarize.
Incorrect. Cardiac pacemaker cells rely on external calcium instead of sodium for depolarization.
Correct. Cardiac pacemaker cells rely on calcium channels instead of voltage gated sodium channels for depolarization.

body.p: Which part of the heart’s conduction system is known as the “pacemaker”?

feedback.p: Correct. The SA node depolarizes spontaneously and it creates the signal for contraction.
Incorrect. The AV node can take over if the SA node becomes dysfunctional but it is not the primary pacemaker of the heart.
Incorrect. The purkinje fibers carry the signal but they do not initiate it.
Incorrect. The Bundles of His carry the signal but they do not initiate it.

body.p: Blood contains white blood cells, red blood cells, platelets, and plasma. Therefore, blood is classified as __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Nervous tissue consists of neurons and neuroglial cells.
Incorrect. Epithelial tissue consists of cells packed tightly together and is found lining the body and its cavities.
Correct. Connective tissue is characterized by containing multiple cell types and a large amount of extracellular matrix.
Incorrect. Muscular tissue is made up of muscle cells.

body.p: What does hematocrit measure?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Plasma is the extracellular matrix portion of the blood and not what hematocrit measures.
Incorrect. The white blood cells are not part of the hematocrit. The WBC and the platelets make up the very small buffy coat.
Incorrect. The stem cells for blood cells are located in the bone marrow.
Correct. The red blood cells typically comprise about 45% of the blood volume. This fraction is known as the hematocrit.

body.p: Which layer merges with the surrounding tissue to help anchor the blood vessel in place?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The tunica interna lines the lumen and allows solutes to pass between the blood and the tissues.
Incorrect. The tunica media is going to play a role in regulating the distribution and flow of blood.
Correct. The tunica externa is the outer layer and merges with the surrounding tissue to anchor the blood vessel in place.

body.p: The elastic fibers of the tunica media allow for __________.

input.choice: the movement of solute to the tissue
the anchoring of the vessel to surrounding tissues
expanding and recoiling without the loss of tension
the regulation of vessel diameter by constricting and dilating

feedback.p: Incorrect. The numerous spaces between the elastic fibers of the tunica interna allow for solute movement.
Incorrect. The collagen fibers of the tunica externa allow for the vessel to be anchored.
Correct. The elastic fibers of the tunica media allow for the vessel to expand and recoil without the loss of tension.
Incorrect. The smooth muscle cells of the tunica media control the diameter of the vessel by dilating and constricting it.

body.p: The heart is located ___________.

input.choice: just right of the midline in the thorax
just left of the midline in the thorax
just right of midline in the pulmonary cavity

feedback.p: Incorrect. The heart is not located on the right side of your chest.
Correct. The heart is located slightly left of the midline of your body in your chest cavity (thorax).
Incorrect. Your heart is located just to the left of midline.
Incorrect. The lungs are located in pulmonary cavity.

body.p: Which of the following is the correct order of blood flow between the chambers of the heart?

input.choice: left atrium, left ventricle, pulmonary arteries, pulmonary veins, right atrium, right ventricle
right atrium, right ventricle, pulmonary arteries, pulmonary veins, left atrium, left ventricle
right atrium, right ventricle, pulmonary veins, pulmonary arteries, left atrium, left ventricle
left atrium, left ventricle, pulmonary veins, pulmonary arteries, right atrium, right ventricle

feedback.p: Incorrect. The Left atrium receives blood from the lungs after it has already been pumped through the right side of the heart.
Correct. This is the order that blood flows through the heart. It is returned from the body to the right atrium and is pumped back to the body by the left ventricle.
Incorrect. The pulmonary veins bring blood back to the left atrium, the pulmonary arteries take blood to the lungs from the right ventricle.
Incorrect. Blood returns from the body to the right side of the heart.

body.p: Which structure is responsible for tethering the AV valves to the ventricular walls, allowing them to remain closed during ventricular contractions?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The septa separate the chambers of the heart.
Incorrect. The semilunar valves prevent the back flow from arteries into the right and left ventricles.
Incorrect. The chambers of the heart contract to pump blood.
Correct. The chordae tendinae connect to the AV valve leaflets to prevent the leaflets from opening.

body.p: The tricuspid valve closes when the __________.

input.choice: left atrium moves into its relaxation phase and the left ventricular pressure increases
right atrium moves into its relaxation phase and the right ventricular pressure increases
body is trying to prevent back flow from the pulmonary arteries into the right ventricle
body is trying to prevent back flow from the aorta into the left ventricle

feedback.p: Incorrect. The bicuspid valve would be closed when this occurs.
Correct. The tricuspid valve functions to prevent the back flow of blood into the right atrium when the right ventricular pressure is higher.
Incorrect. The pulmonary semilunar valve would prevent this backflow.
Incorrect. The aortic valve would prevent this backflow.

body.p: Which of the following is not properly matched with its description?

input.choice: Pulmonary artery - carries oxygen-poor blood to the lungs
Aorta - major vein caring oxygen-poor blood
Superior vena cava - major vein caring oxygen-poor blood.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The pulmonary artery is one of the few arteries that carry oxygen-poor blood.
Correct. The aorta is a major artery that carries oxygen-rich blood to the body.
Incorrect. The superior vena cava drains oxygen-poor blood from the head and upper body and transports it to the heart.
Incorrect. The pulmonary vein does carry oxygen-rich blood from the lung to the left atria of the heart.

body.p: What structure is responsible for separating the heart from the lungs in the chest cavity?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Both the heart and the lungs are located in the thoracic cavity or chest.
Incorrect. Both the heart and the lungs are protected by the rib cage.
Correct. The pericardium surround the heart and separates it from the lungs.
Incorrect. The ventricles are part of the heart and are responsible for pumping blood to the lungs and body.

body.p: The right and left coronary arteries originate from __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The posterior interventricular branch is a subdivision of the right coronary artery.
Correct. The aortic sinuses receives blood from the ascending aorta that then flows into the coronary arteries.
Incorrect. The marginal branch is a subdivision of the right coronary artery.
Incorrect. The pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs.

body.p: The pulmonary veins __________.

input.choice: deliver oxygen-poor blood to the capillaries surrounding the alveoli of the lungs
return the blood, high in carbon dioxide and waste products, to the right side of the heart
deliver blood, rich with oxygen and nutrients, to capillary networks
return oxygen-rich blood to the left side of the heart

feedback.p: Incorrect. The pulmonary arteries deliver oxygen-poor blood to the lungs.
Incorrect. The veins of systemic circulation drain the capillary beds of the body and return that oxygen-poor blood to the heart.
Incorrect. The arteries of systemic system carry oxygen-rich blood to the tissues of the body.
Correct. The veins of the pulmonary circulation return oxygen rich blood from the lungs to the heart.

body.p: The ductus arteriosus connects the __________ and __________, bypassing the __________.

input.choice: umbilical vein, inferior vena cava, liver

feedback.p: Incorrect. The foramen ovale shunts blood between the atria, bypassing the lungs.
Incorrect. The ductus venosus shunts blood past the liver between the umbilical vein and vena cava.
Correct. The ductus arteriosus shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta, bypassing the lungs.
Incorrect. There is not shunt directly from the right atrium to the aorta.

body.p: Which of the aortic segments contains the openings to the main coronary arteries?

feedback.p: Correct. The ascending aorta contains the aortic sinuses that feed the left and right coronary arteries.
Incorrect. The arch of the aorta divides into the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery.
Incorrect. The thoracic aorta provides blood to the structures of the chest but not to the heart muscle itself.
Incorrect. The abdominal aorta provides blood to the abdominal and pelvic regions and divides into the two common iliac arteries.

body.p: Which type of artery is capable of temporarily storing blood that has been ejected from the heart?

feedback.p: Correct. Elastic arteries have the ability to passively expand to absorb the blood exiting the heart at high pressure and then to recoil back to original size.
Incorrect. The muscular arteries have a thicker muscular tunic and cannot passively expand as much to accommodate that amount of blood.
Incorrect. Distributing arteries is another name for muscular arteries. These arteries receive the blood from the elastic arteries.
Incorrect. Arterioles are smaller arteries that regulate the amount of blood being delivered to the various capillary beds.

body.p: What structure creates redundancies in blood supply to the brain so that if one artery is damaged or blocked there is another route for blood to get to the brain?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The optic chiasm is not an artery, it is the location in the brain where the optic nerves cross.
Correct. The circle of Willis or the arterial circle provides redundancies (anastomoses) to ensure blood supply to the brain.
Incorrect. The thyrocervical trunk supplies blood to the thyroid and some scapular muscles.
Incorrect. The basilar artery is one arterial supply to the circle of Willis, but itself is not an anastomoses.

body.p: Which large artery divides into the common hepatic, splenic, and left gastric arteries?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The superior mesenteric artery branches supply the duodenum, pancreas, and parts of the small and large intestines.
Incorrect. The inferior mesenteric artery branches supply parts of the large intestine.
Correct. The celiac trunk divides into these three arteries.
Incorrect. The median sacral artery supplies the lower region of the abdominal cavity and base of the spine.

body.p: All of the arterial supply of the upper limbs is from branches of the __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The celiac trunk provides blood flow to organs of the abdomen.
Correct. The subclavian arteries do not branch but are continuous with the axillary arteries and the brachial arteries.
Incorrect. The thyrocervical trunks provide blood flow to the thymus.
Incorrect. The common carotid arteries supply blood to the head.

body.p: The right and left common iliac arteries are the terminal branches of which artery?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The aortic arch supplies blood to the head and arms.
Incorrect. The ascending aorta supplies blood to the heart.
Incorrect. The thoracic aorta supplies the chest region.
Correct. The abdominal aorta ends with the iliac arteries.

body.p: High levels of low density lipoprotein in the bloodstream can lead to all of the following except __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Atherosclerosis is the accumulation of plaque in the arteries, one of the main contributors to this plague is LDL.
Correct. Senile arteriosclerosis is the loss of elasticity in the arteries and is related to age not LDL concentrations.
Incorrect. Coronary artery disease which can lead to heart attacks is affected by LDL concentrations.
Incorrect. LDL can form plaques which can break off and block blood supply to the brain resulting in a stroke.

body.p: What feature of arterioles allows them to have fine control over the diameter of the lumen?

input.choice: rich supply of nerves to the muscle cells

feedback.p: Incorrect. The precapillary sphincters of the metarterioles allows for control of blood flow into specific capillaries.
Incorrect. If the arteriole walls were fenestrated they would be more permeable, not more sensitive to change in size.
Correct. The rich supply of sympathetic nerve fibers allows for fine control of the lumen’s diameter.
Incorrect. Arterioles do not contain valves, which is a feature of veins.

body.p: What unique venous system feature drains one capillary network, travels to another organ or tissue, and empty into another capillary network?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Venous valves assist in the one way flow of blood towards the heart.
Incorrect. Venous sinuses are collection points for deoxygenated blood that is moving towards the heart.
Incorrect. Anastomoses are connections usually found between superficial and deep veins.
Correct. Portal veins such as the hepatic portal system collect blood from one organ and take it to another.

body.p: Which of the following does not drain into the superior vena cava?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The brachiocephalic veins drains into the superior vena cava.
Incorrect. The jugular veins drain in to the superior vena cava.
Incorrect. The subclavian veins drain into the superior vena cava.
Correct. The common iliac veins drain into the inferior vena cava.

body.p: Which of the following is not a major vein of the head and neck?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The internal jugular is one of the main veins of the head and neck.
Incorrect. The external jugular is a major vein of the head and neck.
Incorrect. The vertebral veins are major veins of the head and neck.
Correct. The common iliac veins are located in the hip region.

body.p: Which of the following does not accurately describe the veins of the thorax?

input.choice: Brachiocephalic veins collect blood from the mammary glands.
The left brachiocephalic vein is shorter than the right.
Most of the blood from the thoracic wall is collected in the azygos system.
The right posterior intercostal vein drains the chest muscles and empties into the superior vena cava.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The brachiocephalic veins collect blood from the mammary glands and the first 2 or 3 intercostal spaces.
Correct. The left brachiocephalic vein is longer than the right because the superior vena cava is located to the right of midline.
Incorrect. This system collects most of the blood from the thoracic wall and is connected to the inferior vena cava by a variety of anastomoses.
Incorrect. The right posterior intercostal vein does drain the blood from the chest muscles.

body.p: Which of the following is not drained by the lumbar veins?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The posterior abdominal wall is one of the areas drained by the lumbar veins.
Correct. The lower limbs are drained by the iliac veins.
Incorrect. The spinal cord is one of the areas drained by the lumbar veins.
Incorrect. The meninges is one of the areas drained by the lumbar veins.

body.p: Which of the following is not a superficial vein of the upper limbs?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The median antebrachialis is a superficial vein of the upper limb.
Incorrect. The basilic vein is a superficial vein of the upper limb.
Incorrect. The cephalic vein is a superficial vein of the upper limb.
Correct. The brachial vein is a deep vein of the upper limb.

body.p: Which vein is often harvested for use as a coronary bypass vessel?

feedback.p: Correct. The great saphenous vein can be harvested because it is a large superficial vein.
Incorrect. Although the small saphenous vein is a superficial vein, it is too small to be used.
Incorrect. The internal iliac veins are deep, and would be difficult to harvest and would not have alternate anastomotic pathway if harvested.
Incorrect. The common iliac veins are deep, and would be difficult to harvest, and would not have an alternate anastomotic pathway if harvested.
